N9463 county road H
Elkhart Lake, WI 53020

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A 4-year-old white-tailed deer buck named Rusty was found to be toe-touching lame on its left front leg. He was reluctant
to get up or walk and when encouraged to do so, was slow to move and had a severe limp on the left front leg with visible
swelling in the foot. He was isolating himself and seeking shelter under a low hanging tree branch within the pasture.
According to the facility representative, Rusty had been injured in a fight with a 5-year old buck on September 9th. The
facility representative was carrying out food and water to him regularly and monitoring his recovery progress. However,
Rusty had not received any care from a veterinarian at the time of the inspection. (Note- Prior to the exit interview, the
facility representative contacted his attending veterinarian about Rusty and was following the AV's treatment plan until an
exam can be conducted.)
A brown doe fawn was observed to have abnormal amounts of loose brown fecal matter under her tail and anal region
and was in thin body condition. According to the facility representative, this fawn has had diarrhea for a few weeks and
has always been on the thin side even though it is drinking from its mother. This fawn had not received any veterinary
care prior to the inspection.
Providing prompt and adequate veterinary care to diagnose and treat any injuries and illnesses is necessary to prevent
unnecessary pain and suffering. Additionally, there must be a plan for providing veterinary care for emergencies,
weekends, and holidays. Correct by ensuring Rusty and the fawn are examined and diagnosed by a veterinarian and that
the treatment plan is followed according to their instructions.
Expired drugs and medications including 1 bottle of enrofloxacin and 2 bottles of atipamezole were present during the
inspection. The enrofloxacin had been used to treat an antler infection in a white-tailed deer buck a few weeks prior to the
inspection. Expired medications may not be safe or effective and are not an appropriate method for the treatment or
prevention of animal health issues. The facility must ensure that methods of treatment, including the medications
maintained for use in AWA-regulated animals, are appropriate. Correct by ensuring that all medications maintained for
use in regulated animals are appropriate methods for the treatment, control, or prevention of disease.
***Correct by 5pm, Friday 9/27/24.

A photograph was posted online on 5/19/24 of a young woman holding out a coffee can of grain and feeding a bison
within the primary enclosure. There is no barrier between the woman and the bison. The facility representative stated that
the bison is Brandy, a 3.5 year old bison cow that was hand-raised and is tame, but this practice was stopped in June
2024 and is no longer done. During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the
animal and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the public. Allowing the public to
directly interact with the bison does not ensure the safety of the animals and the public. Correct by ensuring that the bison
are exhibited with sufficient distance and barriers between the animals and public to to assure the safety of the animals
and public.
***Correct starting 9/27/24.

During the scheduled tour, there were multiple instances where there were members of the public in the primary
enclosure housing 18 white-tailed deer without an attendant. As part of the tour, 9 members of the public were in the
enclosure with coffee cans of grain, hand-feeding and interacting with the mature bucks, does, and fawns. The attendant
was very knowledgeable, but did not stay in with the general public at all times, periodically leaving for a bit and then
returning. At one instance the inspector noted that the group was unattended for over 9 minutes. Allowing the public free
access without an attendant may lead to injuries. Correct by ensuring that a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily
identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods of public contact to protect the animals and
members of the public.
***Correct starting 9/27/24.

The primary enclosure pasture housing 18 white-tailed deer and 3 bison had a fence post that was broken near the
ground causing the top of the fence to lean inward about a foot at rest. The inspector observed Benny, a 2.5 year old
bison bull, lean on the fence for scratching in that area and the top of the fence line leaned out about two feet then
bounced back after the weight was removed. Having a damaged post that affects the strength of the fence increases the
risk of animal escapes. Correct by ensuring that the fence is structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect
and properly contain the animals.
***Correct by 9/30/24.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The licensee is missing a complete species-appropriate environmental enhancement plan that is required for birds. They
currently have 2 Trumpeter swans on the property. They are providing some enrichment to the birds including a natural
pond and regular feeding and interaction with guests on the tour, but lack a written plan approved by the attending
veterinarian. A species-appropriate plan for environmental enhancement is necessary to promote the psychological well-
being of the birds on the premises. Correct by developing, documenting, and following a plan that, at minimum, addresses
social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions for all AWA-
regulated birds.
***Correct by: October 25th, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A 4-year-old white-tailed deer buck named Rusty was found to be toe-touching lame on its left front leg. He was reluctant 
to get up or walk and when encouraged to do so, was slow to move and had a severe limp on the left front leg with visible

According to the facility representative, Rusty had been injured in a fight with a 5-year old buck on September 9th. The 
facility representative was carrying out food and water to him regularly and monitoring his recovery progress. However, 
Rusty had not received any care from a veterinarian at the time of the inspection. (Note- Prior to the exit interview, the 
facility representative contacted his attending veterinarian about Rusty and was following the AV's treatment plan until an 
exam can be conducted.) 
 
A brown doe fawn was observed to have abnormal amounts of loose brown fecal matter under her tail and anal region 
and was in thin body condition. According to the facility representative, this fawn has had diarrhea for a few weeks and 
has always been on the thin side even though it is drinking from its mother. This fawn had not received any veterinary 
care prior to the inspection. 
 
Providing prompt and adequate veterinary care to diagnose and treat any injuries and illnesses is necessary to prevent 
unnecessary pain and suffering. Additionally, there must be a plan for providing veterinary care for emergencies, 
weekends, and holidays. Correct by ensuring Rusty and the fawn are examined and diagnosed by a veterinarian and that 
the treatment plan is followed according to their instructions.  
 
Expired drugs and medications including 1 bottle of enrofloxacin and 2 bottles of atipamezole were present during the 
inspection. The enrofloxacin had been used to treat an antler infection in a white-tailed deer buck a few weeks prior to the 
inspection. Expired medications may not be safe or effective and are not an appropriate method for the treatment or 
prevention of animal health issues. The facility must ensure that methods of treatment, including the medications 
maintained for use in AWA-regulated animals, are appropriate. Correct by ensuring that all medications maintained for 
use in regulated animals are appropriate methods for the treatment, control, or prevention of disease. 
 
***Correct by 5pm, Friday 9/27/24.

2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
A photograph was posted online on 5/19/24 of a young woman holding out a coffee can of grain and feeding a bison 
within the primary enclosure. There is no barrier between the woman and the bison. The facility representative stated that 
the bison is Brandy, a 3.5 year old bison cow that was hand-raised and is tame, but this practice was stopped in June 
2024 and is no longer done. During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the 
animal and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the public. Allowing the public to 
directly interact with the bison does not ensure the safety of the animals and the public. Correct by ensuring that the bison 
are exhibited with sufficient distance and barriers between the animals and public to to assure the safety of the animals 
and public.  
 
***Correct starting 9/27/24. 
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
During the scheduled tour, there were multiple instances where there were members of the public in the primary 
enclosure housing 18 white-tailed deer without an attendant. As part of the tour, 9 members of the public were in the 
enclosure with coffee cans of grain, hand-feeding and interacting with the mature bucks, does, and fawns. The attendant 
was very knowledgeable, but did not stay in with the general public at all times, periodically leaving for a bit and then 
returning. At one instance the inspector noted that the group was unattended for over 9 minutes. Allowing the public free 
access without an attendant may lead to injuries. Correct by ensuring that a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily 
identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods of public contact to protect the animals and 
members of the public.  
 
***Correct starting 9/27/24. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The primary enclosure pasture housing 18 white-tailed deer and 3 bison had a fence post that was broken near the 
ground causing the top of the fence to lean inward about a foot at rest. The inspector observed Benny, a 2.5 year old 
bison bull, lean on the fence for scratching in that area and the top of the fence line leaned out about two feet then 
bounced back after the weight was removed. Having a damaged post that affects the strength of the fence increases the 
risk of animal escapes. Correct by ensuring that the fence is structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect 
and properly contain the animals.  
 
***Correct by 9/30/24. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.

The licensee is missing a complete species-appropriate environmental enhancement plan that is required for birds. They 
currently have 2 Trumpeter swans on the property. They are providing some enrichment to the birds including a natural 
pond and regular feeding and interaction with guests on the tour, but lack a written plan approved by the attending 
veterinarian. A species-appropriate plan for environmental enhancement is necessary to promote the psychological well-
being of the birds on the premises. Correct by developing, documenting, and following a plan that, at minimum, addresses 
social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions for all AWA-
regulated birds. 
 
***Correct by: October 25th, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
